questions.text: FISTO classification is used for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trachoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Alkali Injury : The classification for ocular chemical burns, like alkali injuries, is typically the Roper-Hall or Dua classification. These systems assess the extent of limbal ischemia and corneal damage to predict prognosis.

  • • Roper Hall classification of alkali injuries.
  • • Option B. Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis ( VKC ) is often graded based on the severity and type of conjunctival changes , such as papillary hypertrophy and corneal involvement . However, the FISTO classification is not used for VKC.

  • • papillary hypertrophy
  • • corneal involvement
  • • Option D. Ocular herpes simplex is typically diagnosed based on clinical features and confirmed by laboratory tests . Classification systems for herpes simplex keratitis focus on the location and type of the lesions (e.g., dendritic ulcers , stromal keratitis ), rather than using the FISTO classification.
  • • Option D.
  • • clinical features
  • • confirmed
  • • laboratory tests
  • • herpes simplex keratitis
  • • location
  • • type
  • • lesions
  • • dendritic ulcers
  • • stromal keratitis

  • ➤ The FISTO classification is specifically used for grading Trachoma , assessing the presence and severity of Follicles , Inflammation , Scarring , Trichiasis , and Opacity to guide treatment and prognostic evaluation .

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of itching, redness, and mucous discharge from both eyes, particularly during the spring and summer months. On examination, you observe the presence of giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of immunologic reaction is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Type 1 Hypersensitivity Reaction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Type 2 Hypersensitivity Reaction involves antibodies ( IgG or IgM ) directed against cell surface or tissue antigens , leading to cell damage . This mechanism is typically involved in diseases where there is a reaction against self-antigens or modified host cells , and it is not associated with VKC.
  • • Option B. Type 2 Hypersensitivity Reaction
  • • IgG or IgM
  • • cell surface
  • • tissue antigens
  • • leading
  • • cell damage
  • • involved
  • • diseases
  • • against self-antigens
  • • modified host cells
  • • Option C. Type 3 Hypersensitivity Reaction involves the formation of immune complexes ( antigen-antibody complexes ) that deposit in tissues and cause inflammation . Commonly seen in conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus and serum sickness , it is not the mechanism involved in VKC.
  • • Option C. Type 3 Hypersensitivity Reaction
  • • formation
  • • immune complexes
  • • antigen-antibody complexes
  • • deposit
  • • tissues
  • • inflammation
  • • systemic lupus erythematosus
  • • serum sickness
  • • Option D. Type 4 Hypersensitivity Reaction , also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity , this reaction is cell-mediated , primarily involving T cells . It is the mechanism behind conditions such as contact dermatitis and tuberculosis skin tests , but not VKC.
  • • Option D. Type 4 Hypersensitivity Reaction
  • • delayed-type hypersensitivity
  • • cell-mediated
  • • T cells
  • • contact dermatitis
  • • tuberculosis skin tests

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The symptoms and signs of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis, such as itching , redness , mucous discharge , and giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva , are indicative of a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction , where IgE - mediated immune responses play a central role in the pathogenesis of the condition

questions.text: A 25-year-old individual presents to the clinic with sudden-onset severe eye redness, copious purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling. The patient reports recent unprotected high risk sexual contact. What is the most likely causative organism of this hyperacute conjunctivitis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gonococcus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Pseudomonas Aeruginosa, a less common cause of conjunctivitis , is typically associated with contact lens wearers . While it can cause a severe and sight-threatening infection , it is not typically associated with the sexual transmission or the severe purulent discharge seen in gonococcal conjunctivitis.
  • • Option B
  • • Pseudomonas
  • • less common
  • • conjunctivitis
  • • contact lens wearers
  • • severe
  • • sight-threatening infection
  • • Option C. Chlamydia Trachomatis can cause inclusion conjunctivitis , particularly in sexually active young adults . However, its presentation is usually more subacute or chronic , and not as hyperacute or severely purulent as gonococcal conjunctivitis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Chlamydia
  • • inclusion conjunctivitis
  • • sexually active young adults
  • • more subacute
  • • chronic
  • • Option D. Adenovirus is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis , often leading to watery discharge , irritation , and conjunctival redness . However, adenoviral infections do not typically cause the severe purulent discharge or the marked eyelid swelling seen in gonococcal conjunctivitis.
  • • Option D. Adenovirus
  • • viral conjunctivitis
  • • watery discharge
  • • irritation
  • • conjunctival redness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In a young adult presenting with sudden-onset severe eye redness , copious purulent discharge , and marked eyelid swelling , especially with a history of high-risk sexual behavior , gonococcal conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most likely diagnosis . Prompt identification and treatment are crucial to prevent complications .

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active female presents to the emergency department with redness, purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling in the left eye. On further evaluation, the diagnosis of gonococcal conjunctivitis is confirmed. Which of the following complications is the patient at the highest risk for if left untreated?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Cataract Formation: While cataract formation is a potential complication of ocular infections , it is not the primary concern in gonococcal conjunctivitis. Corneal involvement and subsequent complications are more common in this condition.
  • • Option B. Cataract Formation:
  • • cataract formation
  • • ocular infections
  • • Corneal involvement
  • • Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is not typically associated with gonococcal conjunctivitis. It occurs due to the separation of the retina from the underlying tissue and is not a common sequela of this type of conjunctivitis.
  • • Option C. Retinal Detachment:
  • • separation
  • • retina
  • • underlying tissue
  • • Option D. Optic Neuritis: Optic neuritis refers to inflammation of the optic nerve and can lead to vision impairment . It is not a direct complication of gonococcal conjunctivitis. Complications in gonococcal conjunctivitis usually involve the anterior segment of the eye , such as the cornea .
  • • Option D. Optic Neuritis:
  • • inflammation
  • • optic nerve
  • • vision impairment
  • • gonococcal conjunctivitis
  • • involve
  • • anterior segment
  • • eye
  • • cornea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The patient with gonococcal conjunctivitis is at the highest risk for the complication of Corneal ulceration . This complication can result in significant vision loss and highlights the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of gonococcal conjunctivitis to prevent severe ocular damage .

questions.text: A 22-year-old male, came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of pain, redness, watering in the eyes along with photophobia since 2 days. After examination, a diagnosis of haemorrhagic conjunctivitis is made. Which is the most common causative organism of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. While adenovirus is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis , it typically does not cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. The conjunctivitis caused by adenovirus is usually characterized by watery discharge , redness , and follicular conjunctival reaction .
  • • Option A.
  • • viral conjunctivitis
  • • watery discharge
  • • redness
  • • follicular conjunctival reaction
  • • Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause such as retinitis in immunocompromised individuals , but it is not a typical cause of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.
  • • Option B.
  • • retinitis
  • • immunocompromised individuals
  • • Option C. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) can lead to various ocular complications due to immune suppression . However, it is not directly associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.
  • • Option C.
  • • ocular complications
  • • immune suppression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The most common causative agent of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis , which presents with symptoms like pain, redness, watering , and photophobia , is Enterovirus , particularly Enterovirus 70 and the Coxsackie A24 variant.

questions.text: In SAFE strategy for Trachoma, ‘surgery’ stands for correction of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichiasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ptosis, or drooping of the eyelid , is not the target of surgery in the SAFE strategy for Trachoma. Ptosis may be caused by a variety of conditions , but it is not a direct consequence of Trachoma.
  • • Option A.
  • • drooping
  • • eyelid
  • • variety
  • • conditions
  • • Option C. Squint, or strabismus , is a condition where the eyes do not properly align with each other when looking at an object. It is not specifically addressed in the SAFE strategy for Trachoma.
  • • Option C.
  • • strabismus
  • • eyes do not properly align
  • • each other
  • • Option D. A Hordeolum, commonly known as a stye , is an acute infection of the oil glands of the eyelid . This is not a condition treated by the surgery component of the SAFE strategy for Trachoma.
  • • Option D.
  • • stye
  • • acute infection
  • • oil glands
  • • eyelid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the SAFE strategy for Trachoma, "Surgery" refers to the surgical correction of Trichiasis , a condition where eyelashes turn inward and rub against the cornea , potentially leading to corneal scarring and blindness . This intervention is crucial to prevent the progression of visual impairment in Trachoma patients .

Ans. C) Angular conjunctivitis

It is characterized by small, white , nodular lesions ( phlyctenules ) on the conjunctiva . While it causes discomfort and redness , it does not specifically manifest as angular conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department complaining of a sudden and painful loss of vision in one eye. Upon carrying out slit lamp examination, findings include 4 + anterior chamber cells, 2+ flare, a fibrinous membrane covering the pupillary area and elevated intraocular pressure. What is the likely diagnosis based on these observations?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Uveitic Glaucoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Primary Open Angle Glaucoma : Typically presents with a gradual loss of peripheral vision over time, not sudden and painful loss of vision. There is also no association with anterior chamber inflammation (cells and flare).
  • • Option A. Primary Open Angle Glaucoma
  • • gradual loss
  • • peripheral vision
  • • Option B. Pseudo exfoliation Glaucoma is associated with the deposition of fibrillar material in the anterior segment and other parts of the eye. It usually does not present with acute symptoms and inflammation like anterior chamber cells and flare.
  • • Option B. Pseudo exfoliation Glaucoma
  • • deposition
  • • fibrillar material
  • • anterior segment
  • • Option C. Phacomorphic Glaucoma c aused by a swollen cataractous lens leading to angle closure and elevated IOP . While it can present with a sudden loss of vision and elevated IOP , it does not typically present with anterior uveitis (cells and flare in the anterior chamber).
  • • Option C. Phacomorphic Glaucoma
  • • swollen cataractous lens
  • • angle closure
  • • elevated IOP
  • • present
  • • sudden
  • • loss of vision
  • • elevated IOP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis with the combination of sudden and painful vision loss , anterior chamber inflammation , fibrin membrane coveing the pupillary area and elevated IOP is Uveitic Glaucoma .

  • • adenoviral infections
  • • Option C. Serotypes 3 & 8: Serotype 3 is associated with a range of adenoviral infections , including conjunctivitis , but serotype 8 is one of the primary serotypes known to cause epidemic keratoconjunctivitis .

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of a pain, redness, increased sensitivity to light and blurring of vision in left eye. He gave history of ocular trauma with a twig, 1 day back. After examination, the ophthalmologist suspects fungal keratitis and takes corneal scrapings to confirm her diagnosis. The following organism is observed under the microscope for which immediate treatment is to be initiated to prevent further corneal damage. What is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Natamycin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Amphotericin B is more commonly used for yeast-like fungal infections (e.g., Candida) rather than filamentous fungal infections. It can be used in certain cases of severe or resistant fungal keratitis , but it is not the first choice.
  • • Option B.
  • • yeast-like fungal infections
  • • severe
  • • resistant fungal keratitis
  • • Option C. Fluconazole is effective against yeasts but has limited activity against filamentous fungi. It is not typically the first-line treatment for filamentous fungal corneal ulcers.
  • • Option C.
  • • effective against yeasts
  • • Option D. Voriconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be effective against a wide range of fungi, including filamentous fungi. It is sometimes used in cases where natamycin is ineffective or the fungus is known to be resistant to natamycin . However, natamycin remains the first-line treatment.
  • • Option D.
  • • broad-spectrum antifungal
  • • natamycin
  • • ineffective
  • • natamycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the management of filamentous fungal corneal ulcers, natamycin is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness against common filamentous fungi that cause these infections .
  • ➤ effectiveness against common filamentous fungi
  • ➤ infections

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who regularly wears contact lenses came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of severe pain in right eye along with redness and blurring of vision since the past few days. questions.explanation:

  • • treating bacterial keratitis
  • • Option D. Voriconazole is an antifungal medication . While it has a broad spectrum of activity , its use in Acanthamoeba keratitis is more limited. It may be considered in certain cases, particularly for fungal co-infections , but it's not a first-line treatment for Acanthamoeba.
  • • Option D.

  • • broad spectrum

questions.text: Which of the following solutions is used for corneal storage purpose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) MK Medium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. While normal saline is often used in medical settings for various purposes, including as an irrigation solution or for intravenous administration , it is not ideal for the storage of corneal tissues. It lacks the necessary nutrients and balanced pH required to maintain the viability of corneal cells during storage.
  • • Option A.
  • • medical settings
  • • irrigation solution
  • • intravenous administration
  • • Option B. 1% Gentamycin is an antibiotic and is used to prevent bacterial infections . While it might be used to prevent contamination of corneal tissues , it is not a storage medium. Alone, it does not provide the necessary environment to preserve the viability and function of corneal cells.
  • • Option B.
  • • antibiotic
  • • prevent bacterial infections
  • • prevent contamination
  • • corneal tissues
  • • Option C. 0.3% Formaldehyde is a preservative and a disinfectant but is not suitable for the storage of living tissues like the cornea. It is used in tissue fixation for histological purposes because it preserves tissue structure by cross-linking proteins , but this process also kills the cells , making it unsuitable for corneal storage where the goal is to keep the cells alive and functional .
  • • Option C.
  • • preservative
  • • disinfectant
  • • tissue fixation
  • • histological purposes
  • • preserves tissue structure

  • • kills

  • • keep the cells alive
  • • functional

questions.text: Which among the following is not true about subconjunctival haemorrhage?

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs due to sudden rupture of conjunctival capillaries

options.label: B
options.text: Blood dyscrasias like anemia, leukemia can cause SCH

options.label: C
options.text: Assurance is the most important part of treatment

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Occurs due to sudden rupture of conjunctival capillaries: This is true . Subconjunctival hemorrhage typically occurs due to the spontaneous rupture of small blood vessels in the conjunctiva . This can happen due to minor trauma , sudden increases in pressure (like coughing , sneezing , or straining ), or even spontaneously without a clear cause .
  • • Option A.
  • • true
  • • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
  • • spontaneous rupture
  • • small blood vessels
  • • conjunctiva
  • • minor trauma
  • • increases
  • • pressure
  • • coughing
  • • sneezing
  • • straining
  • • spontaneously
  • • without
  • • clear cause
  • • Option B. Blood dyscrasias like anemia, leukemia can cause SCH : This is also true . Blood dyscrasias (disorders related to the blood) such as anemia or leukemia can predispose an individual to SCH . These conditions can affect the clotting mechanism or the integrity of blood vessels , making them more susceptible to bleeding .
  • • Option B.
  • • :
  • • true
  • • anemia
  • • leukemia
  • • predispose
  • • individual
  • • SCH
  • • affect
  • • clotting mechanism
  • • integrity
  • • blood vessels
  • • more susceptible
  • • bleeding
  • • Option C. Assurance is the most important part of treatment : This statement is generally true . In most cases, subconjunctival hemorrhage is a benign , self-limiting condition that does not require specific medical treatment . The primary approach is to reassure the patient about the nature of the condition, as it often resolves on its own without intervention . However, if an underlying systemic cause is suspected, such as hypertension or a blood dyscrasia, appropriate medical evaluation and treatment for these conditions are necessary.
  • • Option C.
  • • :
  • • true
  • • benign
  • • self-limiting condition
  • • does not require
  • • specific medical treatment
  • • primary approach
  • • reassure
  • • nature
  • • often resolves
  • • without intervention

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subcinjunctival Haemorrhage occurs due to sudden rupture of conjunctival capillaries , or blood dyscrasias . Assurance is an important part of treatment .
  • ➤ sudden rupture

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism through which Netarsudil acts?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increases Uveoscleral Outflow

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Increasing trabecular outflow facilitates the outflow of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork pathway , thereby lowering intraocular pressure .
  • • Option A. Increasing trabecular outflow
  • • outflow
  • • aqueous humor
  • • trabecular meshwork pathway
  • • lowering intraocular pressure
  • • Option B. By inhibiting Rho kinase , Netarsudil can also lead to a decrease in episcleral venous pressure , contributing to its pressure-lowering effect .
  • • Option B.
  • • inhibiting Rho kinase
  • • Netarsudil
  • • decrease
  • • episcleral venous pressure
  • • pressure-lowering effect
  • • Option C. Decreasing aqueous production : Although not its primary mechanism, Netarsudil may slightly reduce the production of aqueous humor , further aiding in the reduction of intraocular pressure .
  • • Option C.
  • • Netarsudil
  • • slightly reduce
  • • production
  • • aqueous humor
  • • aiding
  • • reduction
  • • intraocular pressure
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Netarsudil lowers intraocular pressure primarily by increasing trabecular outflow and decreasing episcleral venous pressure , but it does not significantly increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • • lowers intraocular pressure
  • • increasing trabecular outflow
  • • decreasing episcleral venous pressure

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the OPD with complaints of sudden onset Severe Pain in Right Eye since morning. Examination showed Circumcorneal Congestion & Shallow Anterior Chamber. What is the probable Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Angle Closure Attack

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Primary open-angle glaucoma: Insidious onset and usually asymptomatic initially with mild headache and ocular pain . May have history of frequent change in near vision glasses.
  • • Option A
  • • Insidious onset
  • • asymptomatic
  • • mild headache
  • • ocular pain
  • • Option B . Pseudo-Exfoliation Glaucoma: Amorphous grey dandruff-like material deposition on pupillary border , anterior lens surface, posterior iris surface , zonules , ciliary process and blockage of trabecular meshwork with the same . Clinically usually behaves like POAG , but can present as ACG also.
  • • Option B
  • • Amorphous grey
  • • material deposition
  • • pupillary border
  • • anterior lens surface,
  • • posterior iris surface
  • • zonules
  • • ciliary process
  • • blockage
  • • trabecular meshwork
  • • same
  • • POAG
  • • Option D . Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma: Can present with intermittent symptoms of Blurring and Haloes due to Corneal Epithelial Oedema or acutely with markedly Decreased Vision and Ocular/Periocular Pain and Headache (like in the question, for which a more suitable answer is Acute Angle Closure Attack ).
  • • Option D
  • • intermittent symptoms
  • • Blurring
  • • Haloes
  • • Corneal Epithelial Oedema
  • • Decreased Vision
  • • Ocular/Periocular Pain
  • • Headache
  • • Acute Angle Closure Attack

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the classic presentation of an Acute Angle-Closure Attack , which includes sudden onset of severe Ocular Pain , Circumcorneal Congestion , and a shallow Anterior Chamber , requiring prompt recognition and management .

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of painless, gradually progressive reduction of vision of the right eye over several months. IOP was OD: 55mmHg and OS: 19mmHg. Anterior chamber was of normal depth in both eyes. A white flaky disc was seen on the anterior lens capsule after dilatation in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Uveitis Glaucoma is secondary to uveitis . Signs of active inflammation , such as cells and flare in the anterior chamber or synechiae ( adhesion of the iris to the lens or cornea ), might be expected .
  • • Option B. Uveitis Glaucoma

  • • iris
  • • lens
  • • cornea
  • • expected
  • • Option C. Pigmentary glaucoma is caused by the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris into aqueous humor . This pigment can clog the trabecular meshwork , increasing intraocular pressure . Typical signs include mid-peripheral iris transillumination defects , dense pigmentation of the trabecular meshwork , and a Krukenberg spindle (a vertical deposition of pigment on the corneal endothelium ).

  • • corneal endothelium
  • • Option D. Traumatic glaucoma can occur following an injury to the eye and can present with various signs depending on the mechanism of injury . Features might include irregularities of the pupil , signs of angle recession .

questions.text: Identify the sign.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Krukenberg Spindle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pseudo-Exfoliation: The anterior lens capsule commonly exhibits a central disc with a peripheral layer of pseudoexfoliative material that shows radial indentations . These two components are separated by a clear zone , which is maintained through abrasion caused by the movement of the pupil .
  • • Option A. Pseudo-Exfoliation:
  • • anterior lens capsule
  • • exhibits
  • • central disc

  • • pupil
  • • Option B. Sampaolesi Line: Refers to pigment deposits that can be observed on or anterior to the Schwalbe's line , particularly in heavily pigmented angles like seen in Pseudoexfoliation syndrome .
  • • Option B. Sampaolesi Line:
  • • pigment deposits
  • • observed
  • • anterior
  • • Schwalbe's line
  • • heavily pigmented angles
  • • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome
  • • Option C. Glaukomflecken: Refers to small , focal areas of anterior grey-white subcapsular or capsular opacities that develop within the pupillary area . These opacities are considered pathognomonic of previous episodes of acute congestive angle closure and represent focal infarcts of the lens epithelium .
  • • Option C. Glaukomflecken:
  • • small
  • • focal areas
  • • anterior grey-white subcapsular
  • • capsular opacities
  • • pupillary area
  • • opacities

  • • represent focal infarcts
  • • lens epithelium

questions.text: In which type of keratoconjunctivitis are Horner-Tranta-spots observed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vernal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Phlyctenular Keratoconjunctivitis is an allergic , non-infectious type of conjunctivitis , often associated with tuberculosis or staphylococcal infections . It is characterized by the presence of small , whitish-yellow nodules ( phlyctenules ) on the conjunctiva or cornea , but not Horner-Tranta spots.
  • • Option A. Phlyctenular Keratoconjunctivitis
  • • allergic

  • • whitish-yellow nodules
  • • phlyctenules
  • • conjunctiva
  • • cornea
  • • Option C. Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis is a highly contagious viral conjunctivitis , caused by adenovirus , particularly serotypes 8 , 19 , and 37 . Symptoms include watery discharge , red eye , and photophobia . Follicles on the conjunctiva , not Horner-Tranta spots, are a characteristic finding .
  • • Option C. Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis
